Award.AwardTitle: Participation in the Construction and Operation of the CUORE and Majorana Neutrinoless Double-Beta Decay Experiments
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will enable the group to continue a comprehensive program in neutrino-less double-beta decay (NDBD). The intellectual merit of this activity is based on the fact that NDBD is the only practical way to determine if neutrinos are Majorana particles (their own antiparticles). This exotic decay is the most sensitive test of lepton number conservation, an important symmetry in elementary-particle physics. If indeed neutrinos are Majorana particles, a measurement of the NDBD half-life would yield the effective Majorana mass of the electron neutrino. Combined with neutrino oscillation data, it would determine all three neutrino mass eigenvalues. Leptogenesis in the early universe is only possible if there are Majorana neutrinos. The laboratory observation and measurement of NDBD would be transformative of elementary particle physics, astrophysics and cosmology.

The group is working on two NDBD experiments: CUORE and MAJORANA. USC has the major tasks of the procurement, production, installation, and maintenance of the front-end CUORE electronic system from the detector to the data acquisition system, and is involved in the construction and operation of CUORE-0, the first tower of CUORE. USC leads a major Task in the MAJORANA DEMONSTRATOR R&D which has the responsibility for the procurement of enriched germanium oxide, its reduction to metal, zone refinement to detector quality metal, and reprocessing of scrap material. USC led the construction and operation of the facility for the germanium (Ge) processing.

Broader Impacts: Discovery would make important contributions to astrophysics and cosmology. New Ge-detector technology developed in this program is now used in National and Homeland security. Students are being trained in cryogenic technology for other basic and applied sciences and in advanced computational methods. The USC group has a new program of outreach to high school students and teachers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Award NSF #1307204 Outcomes Report

The neutrino is the most prolific elementary particle in the universe, yet its mass scale and its particle-antiparticle properties are still unknown. This missing information is needed to complete our “standard model” of elementary particle physics. Also, its properties may hold important information in cosmology, namely their possible role in the evolution of the universe. Neutrinos are created in the stars, including our sun, in nuclear radioactive beta decay, and in nuclear reactors, as well as in elementary particle and nuclear reactions using accelerators.

In normal beta decay, nuclei decay by emitting one beta particle and one anti-neutrino, thereby changing their atomic number by one unit. Some nuclei can decay by emitting two beta particles and two anti-neutrinos. This process, called double-beta decay, has been measured in a dozen or so nuclei. This decay process changes the atomic number by two, to another element. However, the specific properties of neutrinos mentioned above are best probed by observing an exotic hypothesized nuclear radioactive double-beta decay in which the neutrino, if it is its own anti-particle, is emitted and immediately reabsorbed by the nucleus, so that only the two beta particles actually emerge. Observation of this decay would prove that neutrinos are indeed their own anti-particles, and a measurement of the half-life of the process could be used to determine the neutrino mass-scale.  In addition, the observation of no-neutrino (neutrino-less) double-beta decay would violate an important law in particle physics called lepton number conservation. 

The importance of searching for this exotic process was stated in the Joint Study on the Future of Neutrino Physics, convened by the American Physical Society. One of the three main recommendations was:  We recommend, as a high priority, a phased program of sensitive searches for neutrinoless nuclear double beta decay.  Accordingly, the Physics Division of the National Science Foundation is funding several experimental programs like the one reported on here. The Final Report, for which this is the Outcomes Report, describes the scientific activities of the Particle Astrophysics Group at the University of South Carolina (USC) on the two neutrino-less double-beta decay experiments, CUORE and Majorana.

CUORE (Cryogenic Observatory for Rare Events) is a 750-kilogram array of low-temperature detectors, called bolometers, which are single crystals of tellurium dioxide, with the chemical symbol, TeO2. These crystals are cooled to temperatures of ten one thousandth of a degree absolute. A double-beta decay occurring in a crystal causes a very tiny rise in temperature proportional to the energy deposited. The refrigerator (dilution refrigerator) required to cool this large array to such a low temperature is the largest such device in the world. It is located and operated in the National Laboratory of Gran Sasso, in Assergi Italy. The main construction responsibility of the University of South Carolina group supported by this grant was the fabrication of all of the front-end electronics. The USC Principal Investigator and his team worked on the planning and design of CUORE and the construction and operation of CUORE and its prototypes for 20 years. As of last year, CUORE has been operating and accumulating sensitive data in search of the neutrino-less double beta decay of the isotope tellurium-130. It is anticipated that CUORE will operate in the present configuration for about five years. The plan is that in the future the present crystals, which are made from natural 34% abundance Te-130, will be replaced with crystals made with Te enriched to greater than 90% abundance in Te-130. The research and development to achieve this is being led by the USC group. This will increase the sensitivity of the experiment; however, there are purity issues with the enriched isotope that are being addressed. 

The other project supported by this grant is the Majorana Demonstrator.This experiment has the same scientific goals as CUORE, but it searches for the exotic decay in the isotope germanium-76 instead of Tellurium-130. Again the source and detector are the same, but the germanium detectors are fabricated from germanium enriched to 88% in the isotope germanium-76. The University of South Carolina’s responsibility was the reduction of the very costly enriched germanium dioxide into germanium metal, and then purifying the metal by a procedure called zone refinement. To achieve this, the team set up a plant, purchased the equipment and supervised a team in the operation. The result was 35 high-quality detectors that have produced excellent data, placing important upper bounds on the rate of decay of this process. 

Both of these detectors continue to search for this exotic decay, while R&D is underway to upgrade both experiments to significantly increase their sensitivities. The future activities of the USC group will be towards upgrading both experiments towards a discovery.
